What is on the
Tech Radar?

On the Tech Radar

  • JSPM


    Jspm is a JavaScript package manager
    Works with SystemJS universal module loader
    Built on top of ES6 module loader

  • CSSNext (CSS 4 polfills plugins pack)


    Converts your code in CSS4+ to CSS3
    Transforms your CSS specs that are not implemented in the more popular browsers into more compatiable CSS

  • PostCSS


    Transforms CSS with JS plugins
    The tools is very small and only includes a CSS parser, a CSS node tree API, a source map generator, and a node tree stringifier

  • Web Workers


    Run a JavaScript process in the background and not affect the performance of the page

  • Service Workers


    Event driven worker that is registered to an origin and a path
    Is a JavaScript file that can control the web page/ website by intercepting network requests and the creation of effective offline experiencess

  • Web-components


    Set of standards created by Google engineers that allow the creation of reusable widgets or components in web documents or web applications

  • Polymer

    Built on top of Web-Components
    A new library that makes it faster and easier to create web applications
    Hasn't been released yet and is currently in Developer preview

  • ES6


    The upcoming sixth mahor release of the ECMAScript language specification
    Hopefully will be approved in June 2015
    Some new features include: modules and classes, block scoping, parameters and spread and more

  • Webpack

    Bundles JavaScript files for use in a browser
    Can bundle CommonJS and AMD
    Highly modular plugin system
    Capable if transforming, bundling, or packaging almost any resource or asset

  • ReactJS


    UI library that was developed by Facebook to help the creation of interactive, and reusable UI components

  • AngularJS 2


    A reworked version of angularJS

  • TypeScript


    A typed sybset of JavaScript that complies to plain javaScript

  • http2


    Second major version for HTTP network protocol that is used by world wide web
    Based on Google's SPDY

Join us at Hack Night!

‹ ›

 

Kenzan Media Hack Night for developers who want to collaborate on projects with passionate peers. Bring your own project or work with someone else. Developers of all experience level are welcome.

 

PA few developers from Kenzan Media will be there to help out as well as provide the essential needs - good attitude, a bit of experience, food and beverages.

 

We get started around 6pm and will keep going until 9pm (or when we can't pry the eyelids open anymore).
